did.abstract: Michigan-based ski and golf corporation, operating twelve major resorts in North America; records consists of photographs, slides, video cassettes, films, sound recordings, promotional materials, biographical information on the corporationâ€™s founder Everett F. Kircher, and miscellaneous office and topical files.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were received from the organization (donor no. 9323) in November 2010.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.
Copying for commercial or media use requires the permission of the donor.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Boyne USA Resorts records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Boyne USA Resorts was founded by Everett F. Kircher whose real passion in life was skiing. As the owner of a small Studebaker car dealership in Detroit in the 1940s, Kircher would each year travel to the western United States in order to ski. The nuisance of traveling great distances prompted Kircher and two other enthusiasts in 1947 to purchase some property close by a small 500-foot mountain in northern Michigan. This $1 investment would become the Boyne Mountain ski and golf center and later Boyne USA.

Today, Boyne USA consists of twelve major ski and summer resorts: Boyne Mountain, Boyne Highlands, and The Inn at Bay Harbor in northern Michigan, Big Sky in Montana, Brighton Ski Bowl near Salt Lake City, Crystal Mountain and the Summit at Snoqualmie in Washington, Cypress Mountain in British Columbia, Loone Mountain in New Hampshire, and Sugarloaf and Sunday River, both in Maine. Boyne USA also owns and operates a scenic sky lift in Gatlinburg, Tennessee and ten golf courses in various states, including Michigan, Montana, and Florida.

Much of Kircher's success rested on both his business acumen and the innovations he brought to the industry. Kircher was credited with developing the first three- and four- person chairlifts and for installing the first detachable six-person chairlift in the United States. In 1964, Kircher installed the world's first three-person chairlift at Boyne Highlands and the world's first four-person chairlift at Boyne Mountain. In 1992, Boyne Mountain began operating the first six-person chairlift in the United States. Kircher also pioneered artificial snowmaking and co-invented the Boyne Snowmaker, the first efficient device for marginal temperature snowmaking. Kircher is also credited with developing many modern snow grooming techniques and equipment. Industry experts credit Kircher with inventing the idea of ski instruction. In the 1950s, he hired former Olympians Stein Erickson and Othmar Schneider to work at the resort's ski school and teach the latest teaching techniques to Boyne Mountain's skiers. Boyne Mountain, Boyne Highlands, and Big Sky continue to operate ski schools today.

In the late 1960s, Kircher worked to transform ski resorts into year-round recreational facilities by adding golf courses on his properties. Kircher began by building the Hemlock Golf Course at Boyne Mountain with his father's Ford farm tractor. Only after developing the nearby Harbor Highlands Ski Area into Boyne Highlands, however, did Kircher begin to invest seriously in golf. In 1970, the 18-hole Heather course, designed by Robert Trent Jones, Sr. opened. As of 2011, Boyne Resorts are home to eight world-class golf courses, including the award-winning courses at the Bay Harbor Golf Club.

Today, Boyne USA is the largest privately owned ski and golf corporation in America. The various resorts owned by Boyne now offer tennis, biking, hiking, horseback riding, and snowboarding, along with skiing and golf. The resorts also offer fine dining, spa facilities, retail shops, and luxury accommodations.
While Everett Kircher died on January 16, 2002 at the age of 85, his family remains actively involved in managing the thriving business he began in 1947.

scopecontent.p: The Boyne USA Resorts record group documents, through visual materials, scrapbooks and clippings, publications, and a scattering of administrative material, the development of northwestern Michigan as an important recreational center. The bulk of the collection consists of various visual media, photographs, photographic slides, albums, videotapes, motion pictures, promotional posters, display photographs, and design images of Boyne facilities.

The records have been arranged into the following series: Everett F. Kircher materials; Boyne USA publications and promotional materials; Topical files; Photographs; Negatives, Photographic Slides; Videotapes; Motion pictures; Art work; Architectural concept and promotional boards; Miscellaneous office records; Scrapbooks and Clippings, and Miscellaneous. The strength of the collection is in the various visual materials that document the development of Boyne USA Resorts from the founding of Boyne Mountain in 1947 to the early 21st century.

The first series, Everett F. Kircher materials, documents the life of Everett F. Kircher, especially in regard to his founding of Boyne Mountain and management of the growth of the Boyne USA. Materials include biographical sketches, correspondence, newspaper clippings, and a copy of Kircher's autobiography.

scopecontent.p: Boyne USA publications and promotional materials, the second series, contains information on Boyne USA's effort to promote its Michigan and Montana resorts. Marketing and sales materials include news releases, magazines, newspapers, brochures, advertisements, and postcards.

did.unittitle: Big Sky of Montana news releases 1973-1976
Northern Michigan publications with references to Boyne USA
Newspaper and periodical advertisements and announcements for Winter and Summer events
Advertisements and brochures used as part of poster board displays
Skiing and golfing magazines, most containing articles or advertisements from Boyne USA
Skiing and golfing magazines, most containing articles or advertisements from Boyne USA

scopecontent.p: The third series, Topical Files, contains various non-visual materials. The series is organized alphabetically and primarily documents Bay Harbor, Big Sky, Boyne Highlands, and Boyne Mountain resorts. Some of the files also cover new business opportunities and some of Boyne's smaller properties.

scopecontent.p: Photographs, the fourth and largest series, documents the history of Boyne USA resorts from the founding of Boyne Mountain in 1947 to 2005. This is the largest and most comprehensive series in the collection and is organized into six sub-series. The first two sub-series make up the bulk of the series. The first sub-series, Albums of photographs, contains albums of color snapshots of Boyne events and activities. Photographic files, ca. 1940s-2000s consists of loose black-and-white and color prints organized by topically according to location. The following resort locations are documented in the sub-series: Boyne Mountain, Boyne Highlands, Big Sky, Bay Harbor, the Gatlinburg Sky Lift, Walloon Hills, and Thunder Mountain. There is also a significant portion of the Photographic files, ca. 1940s-2000s where the location is unidentified. In this case the photographs are organized alphabetically by subject. Subjects include aerial views, buildings, skiing, golf, ski races, golf tournaments, conferences, entertainment, dining, construction, award ceremonies, and people. Additional sub-series are: Photographs Used in Pictorial History of Boyne, Various Topics, Promotional photographs, and Framed color photographs.

scopecontent.p: The fifth series, Negatives, is organized into loose negatives and binders. The loose negatives are organized alphabetically by topic. The negatives contain images of various Boyne properties, activities, construction, and people.

did.unittitle: Opening of Boyne Mountain Golf Course undated
Maps of Boyne Highlands and Boyne Mountain 1996

scopecontent.p: Photographic slides, the sixth series, contains color slides of Bay Harbor, Boyne Mountain, Boyne Highlands, Big Sky, Crystal Mountain, and the Gatlinburg Sky Lift. The images date from 1961 to 2005 and document activities, construction, buildings, and events. The first part of the series consists of albums, mostly of summer and winter events, and the second part of the series consists of loose slides organized by resort and topic.

did.unittitle: Construction of Super Bowl Lift with Helicopter 1984
Exterior and Aerial Shots of Boyne Mountain and Boyne Highlands 1986

scopecontent.p: The seventh series, Videotapes, contains VHS, U-Matic, Beta, and open reel videotapes of Boyne USA events, interviews, and advertising. The tapes date back to the early 1980s and continue to 2003.

scopecontent.p: Motion Pictures, the eighth series, documents skiing, ski racing, and the promotional activities of Boyne USA in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s. The series contains three 8mm film cartridges and 25 16mm films.

did.unittitle: Boyne Mountain Lodge, Boyne Falls, Michigan

scopecontent.p: The ninth series, Sound Recordings, primarily documents Boyne's radio presence in the form of interviews, advertisements, and concerts. The recordings are on eight 3 inch reels and 27 cassette tapes.

did.unittitle: "Boyne Highlands/Travel Michigan," Greater Cleveland Golf Show

scopecontent.p: The tenth series, Artwork, consists of drawing and paintings portraying ski activities.

did.unittitle: Paintings and other drawings of skiers and ski slopes

scopecontent.p: Architectural concept and promotional boards, the eleventh series, contains plans for buildings and grounds at Boyne Mountain and Boyne Highlands and large promotional images for Boyne USA.

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous Office Records, the twelfth series consists of two oversized volumes documenting alcohol inventory and conference bookings.

scopecontent.p: The thirteenth series, Scrapbooks and Clippings, contains scrapbooks of news releases and several folders of news clippings related to Boyne USA provided by a news clipping service.
Miscellaneous, the fourteenth and final series, consists of oversize certificates, commemorative materials, and informational placards related to Boyne USA resorts, events, and history.
